title: events: don't call once twice
WIP events: add execution hooks
body:
This allows developers to hook into key places during the EventEmitter
life cycle.

title: doc: document that `process.send` is synchronous
build: Simplify the logic in vcbuild.bat
body:
While adding support for Visual Studio 2013, I noticed duplicate
logic for VS detection in gyp (MSVS*.py), nodejs (vcbuild.bat),
and node-gyp (lib/configure.js).  The detection logic in gyp is
sufficient for our needs, so I am simplifing the logic in nodejs
and node-gyp.

This change requires node to be built from a VS Command Prompt
as it checks for the existence of VS1x0COMNTOOLS and relies on
msbuild being on the path.

This change also updates the README to specify using a command
prompt, note the support of VS 2013, and add hyperlinks to the
downloads.

title: doc: document `process.env` better
body: Fixes #6424.

title: Aborted unbinded ClientRequests stays on Agent queue and close sockets
body:
node v0.11
 When the Agent reach the maxSockets limit, new requests are pushed to the `Agent.requests[name]` list. At that time, there is not any socket/connection attached to the request. 

If I externaly 'abort' the request, the requests stays in the list and when a socket becomes available, is processed. Then, cause `ClientRequest.abort` makes a 
`this._deferToConnect('destroy', []);` the socket is destroyed when assigned to the request, when it should be available to other pending request.

2 undesired behavior arises: one request waiting that never will be executed, and an unneeded socket close.   

Maybe could be solved with a new 'abort' event? As the `abort` API is not Stream one, makes sense for me to have this event also on ClientRequest

title: unclear errors when reading big files using fs.readFile
Calling listen() on a busy port while using cluster produces EADDRINUSE after port clears
Keepalive socket on `freeSockets` link was hang
body:
I test a lot these days for Keepalive agent on node 0.11.8, I set `maxSockets` and `maxFreeSockets` are same to `10`.

Then I benchmark a while. After remote server down, and the connected socket on the `freeSockets` link wont close.

Then I curl the same url again, keepalive agent will use the hang socket on `freeSockets` to connect the remote server, then the request became a zombie. 

![1](http://nfs.nodeblog.org/b/5/b5bc2337bc7e72ea34df8977fe69b2da.png)

I'm try to repeat this bug in a small test code.

title: domain: does not catch emitted errors when error listener exists, contrary to documentation
src: stop using v8::Isolate::GetCurrent()
body:
v8::Isolate::GetCurrent() is on its way out in upstream V8. Let's be
proactive and stop using it now.

It's up for debate what to do with NODE_SET_PROTOTYPE_METHOD(): it
operates on v8::FunctionTemplate instances and those don't provide
a means to get the owning isolate.

/cc @indutny @tjfontaine @trevnorris - think of this PR as a discussion starter more than anything else.

title: crypto: XTS mode ciphers
body:
XTS mode ciphers return errors. Please see [test case](https://gist.github.com/trevnorris/7341893).

Tested against (static):
OpenSSL-1.0.1e
OpenSSL-FIPS-2.0.5
OpenSSL-1.0.0-FIPS (RPM)

All exhibit same error: ```[TypeError: error:00000000:lib(0):func(0):reason(0)]``` for the ```aes-128-xts``` & ```aes-256-xts``` cipher modes.

When examining the list of cipher/modes available in node using ```crypto.getCiphers()``` both ```aes-128-xts``` & ```aes-256-xts``` get returned, however when examining the list of ciphers from OpenSSL (all versions listed above) using ```openssl ciphers -v``` the XTS modes are not listed.

According to [line 2114](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/src/node_crypto.cc#L2114) which in turn simply uses the ```EVP_CIPHER_do_all_sorted()``` function (available < 0.9.8x) after the call to [line #3942](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/src/node_crypto.cc#L3942).

I am a little confused by this as from what I know of OpenSSL because the XTS mode ciphers for AES are not listed how is node.js providing them in the list as being available? Perhaps this is a compiler problem?

title: Child process hanging
body:
Node 0.8.26

I have a Java app that waits for stdin to close and then prints true or false to stdout and exits.
This is called from Node (see [gist](https://gist.github.com/OrangeDog/63a33a644b03a65d329f)) using `child_process.spawn()`.
Occasionally in our production system, the Java process remains open, and the `'close'` event never happens. Once this happens, all future spawned Java instances do the same thing.

Other Nodes running on the same box are not affected. Sending a TERM to one of the hung processes ends it but no trace of this is seen in the Node logs. Restarting the Node instance fixes this.

Testing with `gdb` on a stuck Java process:

- Closing fd 0
    - process exits abnormally
    - no output shown in node logs

- Redirecting fd 1 and 2 to files, and closing fd 0
    - process exits abnormally
    - stderr shows a file descriptor exception
    - no output shown in node logs

- Redirecting fd 1 and 2 to files, redirecting 0 to a named pipe and sending eof
    - process exits normally
    - false is written to stdout
    - no output shown in node logs.

- Redirecting 0 to a named pipe and sending eof
    - process exits normally
    - no output shown in node logs

This seems to suggest that a particular Node process gets into a state where it can no longer manage child processes properly. It is unknown whether input is being sent by Node, but given that the next line after this in the code is to send eof, and we know that this would terminate the process, I imagine this is not happening.

title: test-http-pipeline-flood.js is somewhat broken in v0.8
body:
test-http-pipeline-flood.js (added to v0.8 branch in 653d4db71f569 as a backport of #6214 fix) does not test mentioned issue properly - one would expect the test to fail with a previous release (the one without the fix, for example 0.8.25), but that's not the case - it still succeeds.

In v0.8, the test sets up regular timeout in https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/v0.8/test/simple/test-http-pipeline-flood.js#L54, whereas original uses connection timeout, but changing this is not enough.

title: debugger: fix unhandled error in setBreakpoint
body:
Fix Interface.setBreakpoint() to correctly handle an attempt to set a
breakpoint in the current script when there is no current script. This usually
happens when the debugged process is not paused.

Close #6453

@bnoordhuis Please review. Is it worth adding a unit test for this change? It's more than just adding few lines to `test/simple/test-debugger-repl.js`, a new test fixture is needed.

title: Compilation of v0.11.8 fails on Solaris 10 and some Illumos distros due to missing libproc.h
body:
Building recent v0.11.X source on Solaris 10 fails with:

../deps/mdb_v8/mdb_v8.c:53:21: fatal error: libproc.h: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.

That's expected. The interfaces in libproc.h are private and the header file is explicitly excluded from packaging, so this will be true of Solaris and most Illumos-based distros. (I suspect you don't realize this for SmartOS, because it ends up in the proto area.)

I can work around this by explicitly turning off node_use_mdb in the configure script, but this ought to be handled properly.

title: writestream should fsync(2) before close(2)
body:
I am having an issue where data piped to a fs.WriteStream isn't flushed to disk.  I think this is because of the way WriteStream is implemented-- it just calls close(2) when it gets a finish event, but it should fsync first.  If you look at the man pages for close, this bit is what I think is causing my problem: 


> A successful close does not guarantee that the data has been successfully saved to disk, as the kernel  defers  writes.   It  is  not  common for a file system to flush the buffers when the stream is closed.  If you need to be sure that the data is physically stored use fsync(2).  (It will depend on the disk hardware at this point.)

On this line: 

https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/fs.js#L1610

It looks like the fs.writeStream calls close when it gets a finish from its source.

This is the function that will be called:

https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/fs.js#L1542

And in this function, it is clear that node is calling fs.close (http://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_fs_close_fd_callback) directly, which will cause the issue I describe above.

I think the response to the finish event should be changed to do an fsync first, then a close: http://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_fs_fsync_fd_callback

I can put in a pull request for this, but I wanted to see if you guys agree with me first.  This is only an issue for me on my production windows server, which has very large disk caches.

Thanks!

title: #3977 Node.js crash on Windows when no read permissions for the root
body:
Fixing an error that was occurring if node was hosted on Azure or shared hosting, and the website user didn't have read NTFS persmissions on the root folder.

Examples:
https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/3977
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12718488/error-eperm-operation-not-permitted-with-node-js-and-etherpad-lite

title: process.env doc insufficient
body:
process.env, in the nodejs process page, just tells us to see man 7 environ.  Unfortunately that says:

     An array of strings called the environment is made available by execve(2) when a process begins.  By convention these strings have
     the form ``name=value''.  ....

yes, this is the world of old C/Unix; the env is always stored as an array rather than a dictionary (which wasn't easy in those days).  with the rule that keys could not contain = characters cuz we all had to parse each string ourselves.  

process.env, however, is correctly a dictionary (object).  This should be explained.  Also, can I write to it by just setting a field?  node-inspector lets me do that but that should also be mentioned.  You could do both with a simple example like process.env.LANG = 'en_US'

title: streamwrap: chainable callbacks
body:
StreamWrapCallbacks should be chainable.

I.e. it should be possible to wrap stream (TLSWrap, or HTTPWrap in near future) multiple times.

title: stream: End writables before emitting 'end' event
readline with multi-line question (\n) repeats whole question on backspace/delete
body:
When a question passed to `readline.question` contains a `\n` character, pressing Enter/Backspace causes the previous questions to be repeated.

Example:

```javascript
var rl = require('readline').createInterface({
    input: process.stdin,
    output: process.stdout
}); 
rl.question('First\nSecond\nThird ', function(answer) {
    rl.close();
    console.log('Result = ' + answer);
});
```

Output:
```
First
Second
Third |
```

After pressing any key, say, "xX"

```
First
Second
Third xX|
```

Now, press backspace to observe the bug:

```
First
Second
First
Second
Third x|
```

As you can see, the last line disappeared, and the whole question is repeated.

Node v0.10.21 on Linux.

title: core: expose gc statistics
body:
Tangentially related to #6412.  It would benefit profiling and monitoring tools if it was possible to obtain (more) information on garbage collection cycle types and durations.

Suggested solutions: add a `V8::GetHeapStatistics()` binding, add pre- and post-GC hooks for timing purposes and maybe look into patching V8 to get more detailed GC statistics.  For example, you currently can't really differentiate on GC runs in the different spaces.

title: core: add v8 cpu / heap profiler bindings

Duplex Streams Bound to Underlying Streams
path.relative() not working with network shares
body:
Method relative() of core module path fail to properly support network shares as used in Windows OS. As it's possible to read a file's content from a network share using a pathname like

    \\\\server\\folder\\sub\\subsub\\target

this limited support in module path might be considered limiting cross-platform support of nodejs. Tested the following code blocks with node.exe 0.10.20 downloaded from nodejs.org.

### Test 1

```javascript
var a = "\\\\server";
var b = "\\\\server\\folder\\sub";
require("path").relative(a, b);
```

#### Actual Output

```
\\\\server\\folder\\sub
```

#### Expected Output

```
folder\\sub
```

### Test 2

```javascript
var a = "\\\\server";
var b = "\\\\server\\folder\\sub";
require("path").relative(b, a);
```

#### Actual Output

```
'C:\\server'
```

#### Expected Output

```
'..\\..'
```

### Test 3

```javascript
var a = "\\\\server\\folder\\sub";
var b = "\\\\server\\folder\\sub\\subsub\\target";
require("path").relative(a, b);
```

#### Actual Output

```
'folder\\sub'
```

#### Expected Output

```
'subsub\\target'
```

title: http: parse the status message in a http response.
body:
Add the ability to retrieve the status message (reason phrase) from a http response.

This change has a dependency on joyent/http-parser#152. The dependent change allows the http parser to parse the status message and make it available to node via a callback. This change causes node to listen for that callback and attach the result to the "statusMessage" property of the IncomingMessage object. 

While the W3C names this property "reasonPhrase", "statusMessage" has been chosen to mirror the recent change that allows statusMessage to be written to a http response SHA: 54910044b33a6405c72ad085915a55c575c027fc.

https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/4584

Thank for you help

title: crypto: `randomBytes` is non-blocking
body:
Add NOTE section in documentation, mentioning that `randomBytes` won't
block when entropy sources are drained.

fix #6372

title: Crypto randomBytes and pseudoRandomBytes
body:
I've been bemoaning the lack of documentation for some of the implementation-specific nuances in Node in both `randomBytes` and `pseudoRandomBytes` that senchalabs/connect#932 assumes will be forward-compatible. Specifically, both `randomBytes` and `pseudoRandomBytes` hook to the [same algorithm][stackoverflow] in OpenSSL. Node's [crypto documentation][crypto] states that `pseudoRandomBytes` "Generates non-cryptographically strong pseudo-random data," which means that it probably shouldn't be used where security is paramount. That indicates we shouldn't use it for, say, session identifiers, except the implementation details--again, see the stackoverflow question--make it so that in most common cases it will generate cryptographically strong random data. Can this really be relied on? If so, can we update the docs to reflect this?

[stackoverflow]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18130254/randombytes-vs-pseudorandombytes#18131768 "randomBytes vs pseudoRandomBytes"
[crypto]: http://nodejs.org/api/crypto.html#crypto_crypto_pseudorandombytes_size_callback "crypto.pseudoRandomBytes(size, [callback])"

title: build: add i18n build option
body:
This is something we'll have to address when we upgrade to v8 `3.22` anyways, since it's enabled by default.

IMO it should be disabled by default, but add a `configure` flag like `--with-{intl,icu,i18n}` (choose one) that'll automatically take care of adding it to the build. Currently in v8 if you do a `make dependencies` it checks out a substantial amount of code for icu. I'm told that there's a much slimmed down version that can be used. Either way I don't think it should be bundled with Node by default. Instead it'll just grab the dependency before the build process.

I was able to build current `master` with i18n support by doing the following steps:

* Added `'os_posix': 1` to the `variables` section of `common.gypi`.
* Added `'v8_enable_i18n_support': 1` to the `variables` section of `common.gypi`.
* Run the following commands:

```
cd deps/v8
make dependencies
cd ../../
ln -s deps/v8/build/
mv deps/v8/third_party .
./configure
make -j8
```

This gave me a build of Node that had the `Intl` global object.

possible dependency: https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/6370
extension of: https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/4689

/cc @tjfontaine @TooTallNate @davglass

title: gyp: allow pass v8 gyp variables to configure
body:
As far as I know, currently it's impossible to pass, say `-Dv8_enable_i18n_support=1` to `./configure` so it's read in as one of the `variables` in `common.gypi`. Is there a way, or will we need to add support for this?

/cc @tjfontaine @TooTallNate

a) a C++ API function for checking whether the debugger is enabled
b) functionality to stop the debugger.

Moved away from using file based PEM & SPKAC for tests to object based
comparisons of example SPKAC's using key sizes ranging from 1024 - 4096,
and hashing algorithms md4, md5, sha1, sha224, sha256, sha384, sha512 &
rmd160

title: File ReadableStream#unshift triggers readable immediately
obtrusive "domain" property on emitter objects
body: making it really difficult to mix into objects that you'd like to consider "plain" emitters. Could we switch to `._domain`?

title: add "reasonPhrase" or "statusMessage" property to http.ServerResponse
body:
I've noticed, that for `http.ServerResponse`, there is a property called "statusCode" but no property called "statusMessage".

Currently, the only way to specify the statusMessage is through a call of `res.writeHead`. But this is problematic, since I might want to define the status message and add some headers later like for example the content-type of the body. I think this was also the reason the property "statusCode" was added.

What do you guys think about also adding the "statusMessage" property? When someone sets it, and then writes to the response stream or calls writeHead without specifying the reasonPhrase,then this value is used instead of the standard "OK".

It would be only logical since there also is the "statusCode" property.

title: Clarified HTTP client callback handling
body: Current HTTP client documentation doesn't specify what happens to the callback parameter of request(). Added documentation based on current code base.

title: NTFS Alterantive Data Stream Listing and Deleting
body:
The current `fs` module can read and write NTFS alternative data streams (NTFS ADS's) however there is no API to list streams a file contains, or remove a specific stream, equalivent to Powershell
```powershell
gi file -streams *
rm file:streamid
```

title: build: install node and static library headers
body: fixes #5112

title: Add path.common(path1/*, ...pathn*/);
body:
```javascript
var path = require('path');

path.common('/lorem/ipsum/foo/bar', '/lorem/ipsum/raz/dwa', '/lorem/elo/foo/bar'); //  => '/lorem'

path.common('/foo/bar', '/raz/dwa'); // => '/'

path.common('C:\\\\foo\\bar', 'D:\\\\foo\\bar'); // => null
```

I have use case for it in few of my modules (using counterparts for now), and I wonder why it's not part of `path` API.

I'll be happy to provide a pull request, but before that I'd like to be sure that you're open for such add on.

title: smalloc: track active number/size of smallocs
body:
Two new APIs are introduced:

smalloc.count(): The number of object that are alive, that have been
allocated through smalloc.

smalloc.size(): The total byte size of live allocated object.


Still needs some cleanup, but basic idea is there.

title: node_crypto: Add support for AES-GCM modes
body:
This adds support for the authenticated encryption mode **GCM** to node-crypto.

**Before**: using aes-128-gcm, aes-192-gcm aes-256-gcm with `createCipheriv` would work, however decryption with `createDecipheriv` would always throw in `final`.

**With patch**: aforementioned modes are now supported. Users have to use `buf = getAuthTag()` after `Final`, transmit the tag with the ciphertext, then use `setAuthTag(buf)` when decrypting. If the data has been tampered with or if no tag is provided during decryption, `final` will throw.

The exception thrown from `final` is currently generic. I can make it more verbose/clear if wanted.

**Limitations**: it's not possible to add any AAD (additional authenticated data) into the mix (or verify it). This could be achieved by adding another method to `Cipheriv`, e.g. `setAdditionalAuthenticatedData(buf)`.

**Other AEAD modes:** The AES-CCM mode cannot be used with the current API because it does not support streaming (the *total* length of the plain / cipher text has to be known when the first `update` call is made). Unless limiting users to 1 call of `update` was ok, of course.
Composite ciphers such as AES-128-CBC-HMAC-SHA1 use a different OpenSSL API, which is rather poorly documented (and only used in OpenSSL's TLS implementation as far as I can tell), so supporting these is not currently in scope of this pull request either.

Thanks for considering.

title: src: emit 'beforeExit' event on process object
body:
Unlike the 'exit' event, this event allows the user to schedule more
work and thereby postpone the exit.  That also means that the
'beforeExit' event may be emitted many times, see the attached test
case for an example.

Refs #6305.

TODO: Still needs documentation.
Suggested reviewers: @tjfontaine @sam-github

title: Add the escapeShellArg function to child_process
body:
When we call external programs via `exec()`, we should escape parameters that may contain special characters.

Let's implement a function that escapes shell arguments.

Supersedes https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/6308

title: http response pause lets event loop exit when there's an actively ref'd connection
http client should emit error on content length mismatch
body:
According to http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html

> When a Content-Length is given in a message where a message-body is allowed, its field value MUST exactly match the number of OCTETs in the message-body. HTTP/1.1 user agents MUST notify the user when an invalid length is received and detected.

We should `emit('error', new ContentLengthError(expected, actual))` or similar.

For too little data we would need to decide if we want to continue to emit the normal `finish`, `end`, `close` sequence, or if it should short circuit.

For too much data it would seem advantageous to allow the user to decide if they want to continue reading or to end the response themselves.

title: 0.11.3 and up break connect.compress middleware
body:
Playing around with 0.11.6 I noticed that the connect.compress middleware was serving garbage to the browser.

Problem started with 0.11.3 as 0.11.2 works fine. 0.10.x branch also works fine.

#### Steps to reproduce: 

simply generate an "out of the box" Express application using the express utility with default options, then add the following line before the *app.use(express.favicon());* line:

app.use(express.compress());

#### expected result:

the default app's css file should be properly zipped and served

#### observed result:

the css file is received garbled up on the browser

title: Added Visual Studio 2013 support to node
body:
vcbuild: Added support for building with Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 in Node.

**Note**: In order for this to be implemented, gyp needs to be updated to [r1676](https://code.google.com/p/gyp/source/detail?r=1676) or higher (I used r1743 to test)

This is a three step addition:

1. Bump gyp to r1676 or higher to get VS2013 support (Not complete, needs to be done by someone with commit access)
2. Edit vcbuild.bat to look for VS2013
3. Add a reference to VS2013 support in README.md


Results:
I ran *vcbuild test* and it passed with no errors. The resulting node.exe was functional.

Discussion:
The current behavior of vcbuild is to select the greatest version of visual studio possible. Is this desirable? Also, should there be an optional command argument for visual studio version? It would be a bit easier to find and work with than setting the gyp environmental variable.

Other:
As this is my first time committing, I should probably mention that I signed the CLA.

title: Submodule documentation should include page navigation
body: When viewing the documentation for a submodule provide links to previous and next submodule

title: nextTick — specifc context
Use of network interface name in Node.js socket programming
body:
You can theoretically have several network interfaces assigned the same ip address. This would be hard on node that uses the interface's ip address to distinguish.

os.networkInterfaces() already returns the network interface name, which is great!

However:

network interface name should also be returned by or be a possible argument to:
- net.Socket.localAddress getter
- net.Socket.connect()
- net.Server.listen()

Please consider this enhancement and I apologize if I am filing in the wrong project.

title: timers: non-deterministic run order with small values

milestone.description: Stuff that should be finished before we release node 1.0

title: feature request: split objectMode into readableObjectMode and writableObjectMode
body:
http://nodejs.org/api/stream.html#stream_state_objects

basically, the docs say "don't touch the stream states except to set explicit object modes". why not have `readableObjectMode` and `writableObjectMode` options in addition to `objectMode` so you can just get rid of this whole section?

for example, in `WritableState`, we can do:

```js
this.objectMode = !!(options.writableObjectMode || options.objectMode)
```

title: events: EventEmitter#listeners should return the user supplied functions
body:
According to the official documentation:

> emitter.listeners(event)
> Returns an array of listeners for the specified event.

When I read this I assume that it will return all original functions that **I** added. But this is not the case, the returned array of listeners also contain wrapped `EventEmitter#once` functions.

Some example code:

```js
var e = new EventEmitter()
function foo() {}

e.once('foo', foo);
console.log(e.listeners('foo')) // [ { [Function: g] listener: [Function: foo] } ]
e.listeners('foo').indexOf(foo) // -1

//
// What I would have expected would be:
//
e.listeners('foo').map(function(fn) { return fn.listener || fn }); // [ [Function: foo] ]
e.listeners('foo').map(function(fn) { return fn.listener || fn }).indexOf(foo) // 0 
```

So we should either:

- Update the documentation
- Return the correct functions

If the decision is made to correct the function, we could add an `Array#map` operation to the `EventEmitter#listener` function which will impact the performance of that function. Or rewrite the `EventEmitter#once` and `EventEmitter#emit` to something like i've done with my EventEmitter3 experimentations;

https://github.com/3rd-Eden/EventEmitter3/commit/b3c9a7038a1e63cb86243fb75faeba8b976d5dd2

Which introduces a major performance improvement for every `EventEmitter#once` and  so far i've seen, a minor degradation of performance for `EventEmitter#emit`

If you're curious about the performance change: 

**before**
```
Count (77825), Cycles (4), Elapsed (5.451), Hz (1182129.0641739992)
```
**after**
```
Count (213030), Cycles (5), Elapsed (5.442), Hz (3775472.889512304
```

And for emitting:

**before**
```
Count (215204), Cycles (4), Elapsed (5.42), Hz (3827804.9657426896)
```

**after**
```
Count (195614), Cycles (4), Elapsed (5.45), Hz (3452276.2521808255)
```

Please note that these benchmarks we're run against my EventEmitter3 library and not the EventEmitter that ships in Node (which is infact much slower than EE3)

title: My v0.13 performance enhancements list

milestone.description: Stuff that should be finished before we release node 1.0

body:
**Things for v0.13**

(note: not sure how much of this is already in place)

Brain spew of crazy things I think will be beneficial to Node.js.


**Thing 1:**

On the JS side, each `*Wrap` that exposes functionality directly to JS
will have it's own very thin `require('*-wrap');` module (right now not
meant to be officially used outside of core). These would offer the most
basic amount of functionality necessary for the module to run, with a
slightly nicer API than just setting a .on* callback on the object.

A very simplified event system that integrates with the C++ module side.
This will involve several things:

- Each class will contain a `Persistent<Function>` field for the associated
  callback that is called directly from `MakeCallback`.

- Callbacks can accept a maximum of 3 arguments.

- A default callback can be assigned that all newly initialized classes
  will automatically receive:

```javascript
var TCPWrap = require('tcp-wrap');
TCPWrap.onconnection(function(c) { });
```

- A callback is passed to each instance that can overwrite the default:

```javascript
var TCPWrap = require('tcp-wrap');
var server = new TCPWrap();
server.onconnection(function(c) { });
```

- If proves to be necessary at this level, instead of an upper level of
  abstraction, a second boolean argument can be passed telling the event
  system that callback should be removed from either the individual
  instance or the default class callback. Though this implementation would
  bring a tremendous amount of complexity, so would be avoided at all
  costs.

- An extremely simplified event system will exist in the case multiple
  callbacks are assigned to the class. The main reason for this is
  backwards compatibility with the current EventEmitter. Basics operations
  are as follows:

  - If no callback has been assigned then the passed function will be
    assigned to the `Persistent<Function>` spot on the class.

  - If multiple callbacks are detected then the `Persistent<Function>` is
    replaced with a super slim event callback that'll be called directly
    from `MakeCallback()`. This will loop through the array of passed
    callbacks, calling each in turn.

  - If benchmarks show that passing empty arguments is a performance hit,
    then the `MakeCallback` will always pass back 3 arguments and just set
    the remaining to `Undefined()`.

- The class that needs to set the `Persistent<Function>` will have a single
  function assigned to do so (was thinking possibly create an EventWrap
  class to reduce code). The flag of which to be set won't be passed as an
  argument but set on external memory using the state sharing technique.
  Since these operations are synchronous, it should be possible to share
  a single location for state that all inheriting classes read from.


**Thing 2:**

Share state with the inheriting class instance and `StreamWrapCallbacks`.
The point being a flag can be set by `setEncoding()` on the class of how
to parse the data once it's come in. This will bypass the need to create a
buffer, then convert it to a string.


**Thing 3:**

Create `HTTPWrap` that will probably inherit from `TCPWrap` and overwrite
`StreamWrapCallbacks::DoRead()` so incoming data can be internally
buffered and then directly passed to the `node_http_parser`.


**Thing 4:**

Have `node_http_parser` call a JS function to create and return all the
object properties that will be returned to the user.


**Thing 5:**

Share state with `StreamWrap::UpdateWriteQueueSize()` instead of needing
to set an object property on every transaction.


**Thing 6:**

`process._immediateCallback` is static, and `_needImmediateCallback` is
simple state sharing. No reason to waste the cycles getting the same
function from the same object every time, or checking the same object
property. Instead persist the function to `env.h` and pass directly to
`MakeCallback`, and use memory state sharing to inform C++ that the
function needs to be run.

title: process.stdout and process.stderr get flushed out-of-order in Windows when piped
body:
When `process.stdout` and `process.stderr` are not piped, writes to them are output in order, as written. When piped, they are written out-of-order. While there seems to be a workaround for the draining issue in #3584, I can't figure out a workaround for this issue.

Given this `translation-party.js` file:

```js
// Test code
var words = "this is a happy test sentence of words".split(" ");

// Test code
for (var i = 0; i < words.length; i += 2) {
  process.stdout.write("[stdout] " + words[i] + "\r\n");
  process.stderr.write("[stderr] " + words[i + 1] + "\r\n");
}
```

In Windows, I see the following behavior.

```
C:\test>node translation-party.js
[stdout] this
[stderr] is
[stdout] a
[stderr] happy
[stdout] test
[stderr] sentence
[stdout] of
[stderr] words

C:\test>node translation-party.js | find "std"
[stdout] this
[stderr] is
[stderr] happy
[stderr] sentence
[stderr] words
[stdout] a
[stdout] test
[stdout] of
```

Can you guys *please* prioritize fixing these stdio piping issues?

title: child_process.spawn on windows doesn't always send all data through stdio
body:
I believe I've found a bug in `spawn`, which is documented here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18907177/how-to-ensure-node-js-child-process-spawn-will-write-error-messages-to-the-conso#comment27911675_18907177

Basically, I can't get the relevant console error message to come through the stdout or stderr of the child process.

I'm on windows 8 with node v0.10.18 .

title: vm: revert contextify/vm2 patches
body:
The new contextify-based vm2 implementation has some teething issues,
notably that it leaks persistent handles and is prone to segmentation
faults and/or debug build V8 assertions because it doesn't manage the
lifecycle of persistent handles correctly.

After some deliberation, I've come to the conclusion that the issues
are pretty fundamental to how the vm2 module is structured and that
fixing them properly will require a fair amount of rework.

With v0.12 around the corner, there is probably not enough time to get
things right.  That's why this commit reverts or partially reverts the
following commits, in reverse chronological order:

  3d4c663 contextify: dealloc only after global and sandbox
  b89b97d src: fix multi-base class ObjectWrap::Unwrap<T>()
  756b622 src: add multi-context support
  fd36576 vm: update API to use options argument
  9c110d8 vm: add isContext; prevent double-contextifying
  a3bf3d1 vm: use MakeWeak to fix leaking contexts
  a54f65c vm: rip out ObjectWrap from ContextifyContext
  9fc0066 src: fix up unused/unordered imports
  48976d2 vm: fix Persistent<Context> leak
  2891790 vm: remove unnecessary Persistent<FunctionTemplate>
  eef5527 vm: Put back display_errors flag
  7afdba6 vm, core, module: re-do vm to fix known issues

Some fix-ups were applied to the restored src/node_script.cc to make it
work with changed internal APIs.  It still needs to be made fully
compatible with the multi-context work from commit 756b622.

Conflicts:
	src/node_contextify.cc
	lib/repl.js

/cc @domenic @isaacs @indutny

title: Http agent doesn't close sockets if stream is piped and destination is closed before end is reached (causes maxSockets to be reached)
inconsistency: should or shouldn't streams destroy consumers when closed?
body:
per https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/stream.js#L87, if a stream emits a `close` event, any consumers will be `.destroy()`'d if possible. However, if you use a [Stream.Readable](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/_stream_readable.js#L461), consumers are not destroyed, just `unpipe()`d.

i am not sure if this is by design or not. personally, i would rather have the `pipe` implementations consistent, so either destroy destinations in both or neither, but i much prefer if `close` events propagated.

title: [process.argv] node debug script VERSUS node script
body:
0.10.18

The path of the script in debug mode is the file name, whilst the path in NO debug mode is the absolute path. Is this correct or both should be absolute?

```
$ node debug script.js
process.argv
["node", "debug", "script.js"]
```

```
$ node script.js
process.argv
["node", "/absolute/path/to/script.js"]
```

title: RFC Events Core events vs. Userspace Events (wrt event propagation)
body:
I was looking at the old issue https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/1480, and it got me thinking: having the core of node use the same events as the userspace puts restrictions on node, specifically with respect to adding in the feature to allow stopping of event propagation.

Now, I understand - and agree - completely that as it stands right now, node should not allow stopping the propagation of events because of these internal dependencies. Here is what I'm suggesting and looking to help out with: separating core-dependent events away from userspace events. What I mean by this is, as suggested in the aforementioned ticket, core sits on the 'end' event in many places. What if we were to emit both the 'end' and a secondary '_end' (or '___core-end__', or whatever, it doesn't really matter, as long as it's reasonably distinct) so that both node can get the events it's looking for, and the userspace gets what it's looking for, AND allow supporting the safely stopping of event propagation.

My first thoughts on starting this separation would be to either: 

* modify all core calls to .emit to add a second call to emit for the event using an event name specific for the core. This would only require modifying the emission and listening parts of the code (to change event types of the listeners, and to add an additional line of code for the emissions)
* modify events.emit() so that the type can either be a string, or an array of strings. The array of strings would contain the original event type (e.g., 'end', 'close', 'bobs-your-uncle'), and one or more aliases (e.g., '__end-core__', '__close-core__', '__bobs-your-uncle__', etc). This would, in my opinion, be a better solution as you only modify the events.emit() calls to add in the core aliases, instead of having to deal with two nearly identical calls to events.emit(). The changes to the event emitter would only need to be minimally changed to support accepting an array of types.

With that said, I think that allowing the userspace to stop event propagation could be very beneficial. For example, I'm working on a system that has a few layers in logic for dealing with socket communications. Depending on what type of data comes in through the socket will determine where in the code a message should be directed - the other layers don't need to know about these messages at all. It would make things clearer from a development stand-point, as well as "safer" as we wouldn't have to worry about accidentally triggering an error due to a "malformed" packet. Right now we are having to code defensively to ensure that certain communications don't get leaked to our message processors. 

Heartbeats are another, more common, example. Pinging two sockets doesn't need to be an application-wide message (it could, but in the spirit of keeping things simple, it doesn't). socket-/engine-io uses heartbeats over the same channel that their normal messages use. As with my previous paragraph, I would have to code defensively to discern whether I need to care about the message, or discard it because it's a ping. If socket-/engine-io could stop propagating the 'message' event on a ping, this problem would be moot, without negatively impacting higher levels of code. 

NB, I could be wrong about how socket-/engine-io's customers listen for messages. I'm not suggesting that socket-/engine-io change their behavior. I am merely throwing a hypothetical out there using a popular library.

I also believe that this could help with module development. It would be very easy to accidentally emit an event that steps on the toes of another module; that is to say, module A could be listening for events 'foo', and react in one way, while module Z happens to be listening for events 'foo', and react in a conflicting way. Now, if the module authors could "namespace" their events for their internal use, this problem would be avoided, without sacrificing backward compatibility and/or a feature their customers have come to expect. 

Okay, that's enough about that. As the title of the issue suggests, I'm looking for comments about these ideas. I am more than happy to volunteer my time in making it happen or even providing a proof of concept, if the node.js community agrees with me that this is something that could be useful.

title: Connection.pipe raises ECONNRESET on afterWrite
body:
So there is this simple server code:
```
var net = require('net');

var server = net.createServer();
server.on('connection', function(c) {
    c.pipe(c);
});
server.listen(10007);
```

And it fails with:
```
events.js:80
        throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
              ^
Error: read ECONNRESET
    at exports._errnoException (util.js:676:11)
    at TCP.onread (net.js:529:26)
```

I'm using node from git sources:
```
$ cd node
$ git log -1 HEAD^|head -n1
commit 204228b57f06ece34b61d69c5e3b58218bbfed0e
```

To reproduce:

1. start server: `$ node server.js`
2. run client: `$ cat /dev/zero | nc localhost 10007`
3. Ctrl+c client
4. see the traceback

title: forked processes ends socket connection if the child takes too long to load
body:
### The problem: A forked process `end`s connections when these 2 conditions exist in the `child`: 1) The child process thread takes longer than ~2 seconds to start. 2) The child makes a `http` request. NOTES: * This is only happens to the sockets that are given to the `child` before the `child` is done loading.
UPDATE: Further testing indicates a behavior where it will hangup the connection even after loading has completed. * I'm running `node v0.10.18` and have not tried on any other versions (yet). * NODE_DEBUG="net http" didn't reveal anything helpful. * This is on OSX 10.7.5 [As discussed in the google group](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/nodejs/4_RvoCtTfHg) this may only be an issue on OSX. I put together a small gist to demonstrate: https://gist.github.com/williamwicks/6477189

title: feature request: implementable Stream.Readable#_destroy() method
body:
right now, you always have to implement the `stream.destroy()` logic yourself. this isn't a big deal, but I wish there were an easy way to implement it as well as consistent semantics and events that occur when `.destroy()` is called (`close` and `destroy` events).

- it should be optional
- i don't know how to handle the case when `.destroy()` is called and `._destroy()` is not implemented

perhaps there is a better way, such as documentation as to how you should implement `.destroy()`. there's absolutely nothing in the docs about it.

title: feature request: public Stream.Readable#dump() method
body:
like: https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/_http_incoming.js#L196

right now, you have to do `stream.resume()` with a comment saying why you're resuming the stream so other people know what you're doing. i prefer if there were a `stream.dump()` method so the comment is unnecessary and users can look up documentation as to why you need to dump the stream.

title: child_process do not communicate  with spawn properly.
child_process.exec() omit Error object when maxBuffer is reached
cli or http: client 'aborted' event or --eval regression
DELETE client request should not send transfer-encoding: chunked
Memory leak when loop  require(file); delete require.cache[file];
process.stdin evaluation results in non-blocking stdout reads
http: every request needs an agent
body: Cleaner Pull Request instead of https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/6131
